questions.question: Question 1: The uterine artery crosses the ureter
questions.explanation:
The uterine artery crosses the ureter anteriorly (Water under the bridge). Damage to the ureter is 
more likely at this site (most dangerous site) during hysterectomy.

questions.question:
Question 2: A newborn child was noted to have a congenital anomaly as shown in the image below. All of 
the following statements are true about this condition except:

options.a: Closure of abdominal wall should be done within the first year
options.b: Bilateral inguinal hernia is seen in males

questions.explanation:
The congenital anomaly seen in the above image is exstrophy of the bladder (ectopia vesicae). It is 
associated with epispadias, not hypospadias. Bladder exstrophy refers to herniation of the urinary bladder through an anterior abdominal wall 
defect. The bladder is open and exposed on the outside of the abdomen. The male to female ratio 
is 4:1. Chronic exposure of the bladder to the external environment can lead to adenocarcinoma of 
the bladder. The clinical features of bladder exstrophy include: • Separation of the pubic bones with non-united symphysis pubis • Epispadias 925 
Sold by @itachibot • In males: Broad and short penis and bilateral inguinal hernia • In females: Bifid clitoris Management involves a staged surgical reconstruction of the bladder and genitalia. Closure of the 
abdominal and bladder wall is done in the first year of life. This often requires an iliac 
osteotomy to relax the tension on the bladder and repair the abdominal wall during 
wound-healing. Later, reconstruction of the bladder neck, sphincters, epispadias, and other genital defects is 
done.

questions.question:
Question 3: 916 
Sold by @itachibot A young girl presents with continuous dribbling of urine but she voids normally. Her parents 
tell you that she had never been totally dry since her birth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with continuous dribbling of urine, in spite of regular voiding, is 
suggestive of an ectopic ureter. Ectopic ureter is a congenital anomaly that occurs as a result of abnormal caudal migration of the 
ureteral bud during its insertion into the urinary bladder. They are usually associated with duplex 
ureters and drain from the upper pole of the kidney. It is more common in females. The ectopic ureter usually opens into the urethra, vagina, and 
perineum. Hence, female patients present with constant urinary dripping all day, even though the 
child voids regularly (Paradoxical incontinence). It can cause hydroureteronephrosis and 
recurrent UTI. In males, the ectopic ureter opens always above the external urethral sphincter. Hence they are 
usually continent. However, it can cause other complications such as orchitis and epididymitis. Management involves re-implantation of the ureter into the bladder to treat incontinence and 
preserve renal functions. If the kidney is severely affected, partial nephrectomy is helpful.

Question 4: During a cricket match, a batsman controls his urge to urinate as he is unable to take a break 
in-between. While batting, he suffers a sudden blow as the ball hits him in the suprapubic 
region. He presents to the emergency department with severe hypogastric pain and the 
inability to pass urine. He collapses suddenly during the examination. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?

options.d: Pubic diastasis with bulbar urethra rupture

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with a history of injury to a full bladder, inability to pass urine, and 
syncope are suggestive of intraperitoneal rupture of the bladder. Bladder rupture can be of two types: Pubic diastasis refers to the separation of the pubic symphysis without concomitant fracture. 
Pubic diastasis with bulbar urethra rupture usually occurs due to straddle injury and presents

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient was rushed to the casualty after sustaining a suprapubic injury. On examination, no 
blood is seen at the meatus. On inserting Foley’s catheter, gross hematuria is noted. His vitals 
are stable and his pelvic X-ray is given below. What will be the next step in the management 
of this patient? 917 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a bladder injury. Open book fracture is most likely 
suggestive of an intraperitoneal bladder injury. CT cystogram will be the next step in the 
management to confirm the type of bladder injury. In unstable patients, a cystogram will be the 
investigation of choice. If an associated urethral injury is suspected, retrograde urethrogram (RGU) is done. Note: Closed book pelvic fractures are more commonly associated with urethral injuries than 
bladder injuries.

questions.question:
Question 6: An elderly man was rushed to the casualty at midnight with complaints of severe suprapubic 
pain and inability to pass urine for the past 24 hours. The abdominal examination finding of 
the patient is given below. A smooth and enlarged prostate was felt in the per-rectal 
examination. While attempting to insert a 16-F Foley catheter in this patient, you feel 
resistance and fail to catheterize. What will be the next step in the management? 918 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Insert a smaller sized Foley catheter

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute retention of urine, possibly because of benign 
prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). The next step would be to insert an 18-Fr Coudé catheter. In men, the BPH especially the middle lobe enlargement obstructs the insertion of Foley's 
catherter. Hence, a Coude catheter is advised over suprapubic catetherization as the immediate 
next step as larger Fr Coude catheter is helpful in negotiating past the angulation in the prostatic 
urethra. 927 
Sold by @itachibot (Note: In acute urine retention, urethral strictures should be suspected when there is resistance at 
the urethral meatus as the strictures are more common in distal urethra than proximal urethra) Bladder outlet obstruction is usually the most common cause of acute retention of urine. Its 
clinical features include: • Inability to pass urine • Severe suprapubic pain • A distended, palpable, and tender bladder Acute urinary retention is managed by placing a urethral catheter as early as possible. Usually in 
BPH, smaller catheters will not pass through the angulation of the prostatic urethra as they are 
flexible and kink. Hence in BPH, the Coudé-tip catheter, which has a rigid and angulated tip, can 
be used to overcome the urethral obstruction. If urethral catheter placement is not successful, suprapubic catheterization should be done. If there is a urethral stricture, a council tip catheter is used to dilate it using a cystoscope, guide 
wires, and urethral dilators.

questions.question:
Question 7: You are asked to remove a Foley’s catheter after a procedure but you are unable to deflate the 
balloon. The surgeon himself tries to remove it after cutting the sidearm but is unsuccessful 
as well. What should be the next step of management?

options.a: CT-guided rupture of bulb of Foley's
options.b: Inject ether to dissolve the balloon and pull it out
options.c: Inject water to over distend the balloon until it bursts and remove the catheter
options.d: Inflate with 20ml of water and under USG guidance, locate and prick the balloon

questions.explanation:
USG-guided rupture of the balloon percutaneously after inflating it with 20ml water should be the 
next step of management. The failure of the balloon to deflate may be caused by: • Faulty valve mechanism • Blockage of the inflation channel by debris • Crystallization of the fluid within the balloon (when saline is used) The next best step in the management of a retained Foley's catheter is to further inflate the 
balloon with 20mL of water, following which the inflated balloon is ruptured percutaneously with 928 
Sold by @itachibot a needle under USG guidance. A suprapubic approach is used in males, while in females, either a transurethral or transvaginal 
route can be used. A cystoscopy should be done to ensure that all fragments are removed. Other methods of approach include cutting the sidearm of the catheter, thereby disabling the 
valve mechanism, or advancing a ureteric stylet or fine-gauge wire through the inflation port to 
dislodge debris or puncture the balloon. But these are often unsuccessful. Option A: CT is not routinely used in most settings with retained Foley's. Option B: Injection of ether through the balloon port causes the rupture of the balloon within 
seconds. But this technique causes significant bladder irritation. Option C: Balloons should not be overinflated until they rupture. This may cause severe pain and 
could cause bladder rupture.

questions.question: Question 8: In the given picture of a Foley’s catheter, what is the function of the tube marked ‘A’?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a three-way Foley's catheter. The tube marked ‘A’ is used for continuous 
irrigation of the bladder to remove debris & blood clots. This is most commonly used after 
any prostate surgery or conditions with bleeding in the bladder. The central tube is used for the drainage of urine and the tube on the right is used for inflating the 
balloon.

questions.question:
Question 9: What is the earliest sign seen on cystoscopy in a patient suspected to have bladder 
tuberculosis?
questions.explanation:
The earliest sign of tuberculosis of the bladder observed by cystoscopy is the pallor of the mucosa 
around the ureteric orifice due to submucous edema. Subsequently, tubercles may be seen. In long-standing cases, there is marked fibrosis and the capacity of the bladder is greatly reduced 
(thimble bladder). This is managed by augmentation cystoplasty. The following X-ray KUB shows a thimble bladder: 929 
Sold by @itachibot Ureteric lesions can also be seen in genitourinary tuberculosis. They include: • Kerr’s kink - kinking of the ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) • Ureteral stricture • Beaded ureter • Shortening of the ureter • Golf hole ureter - Longitudinal fibrosis leading to shortening of the ureter and pulling up the 
orifice as a gaping hole. Reimplantation of ureter is done.

Question 10: A 50-year-old man comes with complaints of hematuria and difficulty in urination for the 
past few weeks. Microscopic examination of urine samples shows parasitic eggs as shown in 
the image. Which type of bladder carcinoma is the patient most likely to develop?
questions.explanation:
930 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario is suggestive of schistosomiasis. The patient is most likely to develop 
squamous cell carcinoma as it is associated with schistosomiasis. The image shows oval-shaped 
eggs with the terminal spine which is characteristic of Schistosoma haematobium. Schistosomal bladder cancers can also be adenocarcinoma or transitional cell carcinoma (less 
frequently). Primary bladder tumors usually originate from the transitional epithelium of the bladder (90%). 
Sometimes, they arise from connective tissue. Secondary tumors of the bladder arise from the 
sigmoid and rectum, the prostate, the uterus, or the ovaries. Carcinoma of the bladder & associated risk factors: Histological subtype

questions.question:
Question 11: 920 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following drugs causes carcinoma bladder?
questions.explanation:
Cyclophosphamide (an alkylating agent) causes bladder cancer The risk of bladder cancer with cyclophosphamide is directly proportional to the duration and 
intensity of cyclophosphamide treatment. Phosphoramide mustard is the primary mutagenic 
metabolite that causes bladder cancer in patients exposed to cyclophosphamide. Painless, gross hematuria is the most common symptom that is indicative of a bladder carcinoma 
until proven otherwise. Depending upon the depth of invasion, bladder carcinoma can be divided into • Flat, non-invasive carcinoma in situ (CIS) • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (70% of cases) - does not invade detrusor muscle but can 
invade lamina propria. • Muscle-invasive bladder cancer - invades the detrusor muscle. Diagnosis is by cystourethroscopy (directly visualizing the growth) and biopsy. Management is as 
follows: • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer: • Transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) followed by intravesical chemotherapy with 
mitomycin C or epirubicin 931 
Sold by @itachibot • Immunotherapy with regular intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette Guerin (BCG) in 
high-risk tumors. • Muscle invasive bladder cancer: Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and 
lymph node dissection +/- neoadjuvant chemotherapy Other options: Option B: Cisplatin is an anticancer drug used to treat testicular cancer. It is associated with an 
increased risk for acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Option C: Taxane is an anticancer drug and is the main component in the treatment regimens of 
metastatic cancers. Taxane's adverse effects are neutropenia and fluid retention (pulmonary 
edema). Option D: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) and is used in the 
treatment of estrogen-dependent breast cancer. Due to its partial agonistic activity, it is known to 
increase endometrial cancer in post-menopausal women.

questions.question: Question 12: Identify the incorrect statement regarding bladder carcinoma.

options.a: Painless hematuria is the most common symptom
options.b: Inactivation of the Rb gene is implicated in the cancer formation
options.d: The most important prognostic factor is the size of the tumor

questions.explanation:
The most important prognostic factor in bladder carcinoma is the depth of invasion. Activation of oncogenes such as ras, c-erbB, E2F3, and inactivation of tumor-suppressor genes 
such as p53, p21, p16, and Rb gene is implicated in the cancer formation of the bladder. Clinical features of bladder carcinoma include: • Painless gross haematuria - Most common symptom and is indicative of a bladder carcinoma 
until proven otherwise • Urinary retention • Constant pelvic pain • Increased urinary frequency • Discomfort while urinating • If there is nerve involvement, pain is referred to the suprapubic region, groins, perineum, and 
thighs. Investigations done for bladder cancer are: • Urine cytology - Low sensitivity • Intravenous urography - Not frequently used nowadays. Replaced by non-contrast CT and MRI • Cystourethroscopy and biopsy - The best investigation

Question 13: What is the treatment of choice for a patient with non-invasive bladder carcinoma of stage 
pT1?

options.c: Transurethral resection of the bladder tumor

questions.explanation:
Since the pathological staging of the tumor is given (pT1), it implies that transurethral resection of 
the bladder tumor (TURBT) has already been done. Therefore, this patient should be managed 932 
Sold by @itachibot by instillation of intravesical BCG. TURBT is done for the pathologic staging of the tumor. This staging helps us to decide the further 
plan of treatment. Intravesical therapy (using chemotherapy or immunotherapy) is done within 
24hrs of TURBT in order to kill any residual cancer cells. It only affects the lining of the bladder

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient with carcinoma in situ of the urinary bladder is posted for intravesical therapy. 
What is the strain of mycobacteria that will be used in this therapy?
questions.explanation:
An attenuated strain of Mycobacterium bovis is used in intravesical BCG therapy. Intravesical BCG is used for the treatment of non-invasive (no invasion into the muscle layer) 
urinary bladder tumors. It induces a strong local inflammatory response against the attenuated 
bacteria, which helps in the destruction of the tumor cells. Option d: Mw vaccine for multibacillary leprosy patients and their contacts is extracted from 
Mycobacterium indicus pranii. It is also used as an adjunct to chemotherapy for category II 
tuberculosis.

questions.question:
Question 15: 921 
Sold by @itachibot Which laser is preferred for performing transurethral resection of the bladder tumor?
questions.explanation: The Nd: YAG laser is preferred for the resection of minimally invasive bladder tumors.

questions.question:
Question 16: An elderly man on follow-up for treatment of bladder cancer presents with painless 
hematuria. Which of the following assays should be done on this patient?
questions.explanation:
An NMP 22 assay should be done in this patient to detect the recurrence of bladder carcinoma. NMP 22 is a nuclear matrix protein that is used to form cell nuclei. It is shed into the urine and 
has a higher concentration in the urine of bladder cancer patients. NMP-22 cutoff levels for 
bladder cancer detection is > 10 units/mL.

questions.question: Question 17: Urinary diversion is indicated in all the following clinical conditions, except:
questions.explanation:
Urinary diversion is not done in cases of bladder hematoma. Urinary diversion procedures are performed to divert urine from the bladder to a new exit site. It 
is of two types: • Cutaneous urinary diversion (External diversion): Urine drains through an opening created in 
the abdominal wall and skin • Ileal conduit - urine is diverted by implanting ureters into a loop of ileum that is led out through 
the abdominal wall. 934 
Sold by @itachibot • Cutaneous ureterostomy - ureters are directed through the abdominal wall and attached to an 
opening in the skin. • Continent urinary diversion (Internal urinary diversion): A portion of the intestine is used to 
create a new reservoir for urine. The internal pouch is placed inside the abdomen. The ureters are 
attached to the internal pouch, and the internal pouch is attached to the urethra or to a stoma in 
the abdomen with a valve. Indications of urinary diversion: • Post cystectomy • Carcinoma of the urinary bladder • Distal obstruction • Neurogenic bladder • Ectopia vesicae, Incurable fistula • Irremovable obstruction • Trauma to the ureters and urethra

questions.question:
Question 18: A patient presents to the emergency department with confusion and drowsiness. He 
underwent cystectomy with urinary diversion for bladder carcinoma 8 weeks back. ABG 
analysis and electrolyte values are given below. Which of the following urinary diversion 
conduits was most likely done in this patient?
questions.explanation:
A uretero-sigmoid diversion was most likely done in this patient as it frequently results in 
hyperchloremic hypokalemic acidosis. Hypokalemia is less common with ileal diversions because 
the ileum reabsorbs some of the potassium from the urine while the colon does not. The order in which the hyperchloraemic hypokalemic acidosis occurs is sigmoid colon > 
colon/ileum. Electrolyte abnormalities based on the part of intestine involved: 935

questions.question:
Question 19: A 35-year-old lady experiences increased frequency of urination and lower abdominal pain 
which is relieved by micturition. Urinalysis is normal. Cystoscopy reveals fissures and 
punctate hemorrhages in the bladder mucosa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with normal urinalysis and cystoscopy findings are suggestive 
of interstitial cystitis. Interstitial cystitis is a persistent, painful form of chronic cystitis, occurring most frequently in 
women. It is also known as chronic pelvic pain syndrome or bladder pain syndrome. Its clinical 
features include: • Severe suprapubic pain • Urinary frequency • Urgency • Hematuria • Dysuria without evidence of bacterial infection Cystoscopic findings seen in bladder mucosa are: • Fissures • Punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations) • Ulcerations in the fundus of the bladder (Hunner's ulcer) The image shows Hunner's ulcer seen in interstitial cystitis: 936 
Sold by @itachibot Treatment options include : • Conservative - Patient education about the chronicity of the condition, behavioral modification 
(timed voiding, bladder training), stress reduction, dietary alteration (avoidance of caffeine and 
spicy and acidic foods) and physical therapy should be the initial management for all patients. • Pharmacological - Neuropathic analgesics (e.g. amitriptyline, pregabalin) are used for those with 
a significant pain component, whereas antimuscarinics and 3-agonists are used for frequency, 
nocturia and urgency symptoms. • Surgical - For those with Hunner lesions, fulguration or laser to these lesions can be beneficial. 
Cystodistension as a treatment has variable evidence for success. If these options fail to improve 
symptoms major surgical reconstruction can be considered in selected cases. Option b: Malakoplakia is a distinct form of inflammatory reaction seen in chronic cystitis. It 
appears as soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques. Option d: Cystitis cystica occurs due to chronic irritation of the bladder mucosa. Cystoscopy 
reveals cystic lesions in the bladder.

Question 20: A child with recurrent urinary tract infection undergoes voiding cystourethrogram. It shows 
reflux of urine into the pelvis and calyces, without dilation of the ureter. What is the grade of 
vesicoureteric reflux?
questions.explanation:
Reflux of urine into pelvis and calyces without dilatation is Grade II vesicoureteric reflux (VUR). VUR is the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to the upper urinary tract. VUR is a common

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following will be seen in a patient with Marion’s disease?

options.a: Hypertrophy of the internal sphincter of the bladder
options.b: Hypertrophy of the external sphincter of the bladder
options.c: Congenital obstruction of the prostatic urethra

questions.explanation:
Hypertrophy of the internal sphincter of the bladder is seen in Marion’s disease. This leads to 
bladder outlet obstruction. Its clinical features include voiding and storage symptoms (usually 
associated with BPH). Therefore it is also called prostatism sans prostate: • Increased urinary frequency • Urgency • Dribbling of urine • Hesitancy • Intermittent stream 938 
Sold by @itachibot • Nocturia It is commonly seen in young patients. Bladder outlet obstruction can occur due to 2 causes: • Muscular causes • Congenital hypertrophy of internal sphincter, i.e., Marion's disease • Dyssynergic contraction of the smooth muscle of the bladder neck (bladder neck dyssynergia) • Fibrosis of bladder neck following transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP)

questions.question:
Question 22: Which of the following is true regarding the condition shown below? 923 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Bilateral in more than 50% of the cases
options.d: Affects males more often than females

questions.explanation:
The given intravenous urography (IVU) image depicts cobra head/adder head deformity which is a 
classic sign of ureterocele. It is associated with dysplastic renal tissue. Ureterocele: A ureterocele is the cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter. It is thought to be caused due to 
ureteric orifice atresia. It is observed more in females than males in a 4:1 preponderance and 
is bilateral in about 10% of the cases. They are similar to ectopic ureters wherein the upper pole of 
the kidney is drained. This condition is typically associated with dysplastic and non-functional 
renal tissue. Clinical presentation: • Children with ureterocele usually present with infection. • Adults present with renal stones. Diagnosis: • IVU shows a classical cobra head sign but is relatively infrequently performed these days. • Cystoscopy shows a bulging, translucent swelling involving the ureteric orifice where there is 
urinary stasis. It is emptied by ureteric peristalsis. Treatment: • Surgical excision with re-implantation of the ureter is the treatment of choice for simple 
ureterocele. • Renal stones associated with ureterocele are removed using an endoscopic incision • An advanced disease that causes hydronephrosis or pyonephrosis is an indication for 
nephrectomy.

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following statements regarding bladder stone is false?
questions.explanation:
A cystine calculus occurs only in the presence of cystinuria and is radioopaque because of its high 
sulfur content. 939 
Sold by @itachibot Primary bladder stone: • Develops in sterile urine in the absence of any known functional, anatomic, or infectious factors 
and does not necessarily imply that stones have formed de novo in the bladder. • Most common in children younger than 10 years of age • Most vesical calculi are mixed • Ammonium acid urate, calcium oxalate, uric acid, and calcium phosphate are the most common 
components of primary bladder calculi Secondary bladder stone: Forms during infection, due to bladder outflow obstruction, impaired 
bladder emptying, or the presence of a foreign body. Types: • Calcium oxalate stones • Uric acid stones - occur in patients with gout but are also observed in patients with ileostomies 
or with bladder outlet obstruction • Cystine stones - in cystinuria • Triple phosphate stones - occur in urine infected with urea-splitting organisms 940 
Sold by @itachibot Prostate
